title: R44693
content: The FMLA requires covered employers to provide up to 12 workweeks of leave for eligible employees for reasons such as caring for a newborn or adopted child, a family member with a serious health condition, or for the employee's own health condition. Military exigencies are also covered. The FMLA provides up to 26 workweeks of leave for eligible employees to care for a covered military servicemember with a serious injury or illness sustained in the line of duty. To be eligible, an employee must work for a covered employer, have 1,250 hours of service in the 12 months prior to leave, and work at a location with 50 or more employees. To qualify for FMLA leave, an employee must work for a covered employer with 50 or more employees within 75 miles, have 1,250 hours of service in the previous 12 months, and have worked for the employer for 12 months. Private-sector employers must have had 50 or more employees for 20 weeks in the current or last calendar year to be covered by the act. Public agencies are covered employers regardless of their staffing levels, but public-sector employees must also meet the worksite coverage requirement. The FMLA has been amended multiple times since its passage in 1993, including provisions for legislative branch employees, military family leave, and airline flight crew eligibility. Bills in the 114th Congress aimed to further amend the FMLA. The FMLA has been amended multiple times since 1993, including provisions for legislative branch employees, military family leave, and airline flight crew eligibility. In the 114th Congress, several bills were introduced to amend the FMLA by creating new entitlements, expanding categories of permissible leave, and modifying employee eligibility requirements. Eligible employees currently have the right to 12 workweeks of FMLA leave in a 12-month period for family and medical needs. H.R. 5518 proposed Parental Involvement and Family Wellness Leave, allowing eligible employees up to four hours of leave every 30 days for school-related activities. Parental Involvement Leave. H.R. 5535 would provide eligible employees with up to 8 hours of leave every 30 days, totaling 48 hours in a 12-month period, for school-related activities or medical care needs for family members. H.R. 5535 would allow eligible employees to take up to 48 hours of leave in a 12-month period for school conferences or activities related to their child or grandchild, with a 7-day notice requirement. This is different from FMLA leave, which requires a 30-day notice for foreseeable needs like caring for a new child or a serious health condition. The 114th Congress considered proposals to expand qualifying uses of FMLA leave, including creating new leave categories and broadening existing ones for caring for a new child, serious health conditions, family care, and military needs. In the 114th Congress, proposals were introduced to expand FMLA leave entitlements, including allowing employees to use leave for bereavement, domestic violence needs, family involvement, and medical needs related to service-connected disabilities for veterans. Specific bills would have allowed employees to use FMLA leave for the death of a son or daughter. S. 1302 / H.R. 2260 and S. 473 proposed expanding FMLA leave entitlements to include bereavement for the death of a son or daughter, parent, or sibling. S. 473 also aimed to address domestic violence needs and family involvement using the existing 12-week leave entitlement. S. 473 proposed expanding FMLA leave entitlements to include family involvement, allowing employees to participate in school activities or attend medical appointments for family members. Employees could use up to 24 hours of leave in a 12-month period for these purposes. Employees could use family involvement leave for up to 24 hours in a 12-month period. H.R. 5165 would have allowed employees to use FMLA leave for hospital care or medical services related to a service-connected disability rated at 30% or higher. Several proposals aimed to expand employees' options for using FMLA leave. Several proposals sought to expand employees' options for using FMLA leave by either (1) expanding the set of relationships for which an employee may use family leave or (2) amending definitions related to the current entitlement. An employee may use FMLA leave to assist or provide care to various family members, including a new son or daughter by birth or placement, defined as a biological, adopted, or foster child, stepchild, legal ward, or a child of a person standing in loco parentis. An employee may use FMLA leave to assist or provide care to various family members, including a son or daughter defined as a biological, adopted, or foster child, stepchild, legal ward, or a child of a person standing in loco parentis. Leave related to a family member's serious health condition may be taken for the employee's spouse, son or daughter, or parent. Military exigency leave and military caregiver leave may also be utilized for specific covered military members who are the employee's spouse, son or daughter, or parent. The FMLA allows employees to take leave to care for family members, including a spouse, son, daughter, or parent. Proposed legislative changes would expand caregiving leave to include a domestic partner's child and adult children. S. 473 and H.R. 5519 proposed amending the FMLA to include a domestic partner's child and adult children for caregiving leave. H.R. 5701 also suggested allowing leave for the arrival of a grandchild, including adult grandchildren. The FMLA definition of son or daughter now includes adult children, and leave is permitted for the placement of an adult child. Proposed additions for needs related to a family member's serious health condition include domestic partners, adult children, parents-in-law, grandparents, and siblings. Military exigency leave may also be extended to domestic partners and adult children. H.R. 5701 and S. 473 proposed expanding FMLA coverage to include additional family members like adult children, grandchildren, and domestic partners for military exigency and caregiver leave. The 114th Congress considered legislation to broaden FMLA coverage by adding adult children, grandchildren, domestic partners, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, parent-in-law, and siblings for military caregiver leave. The 114th Congress considered legislation to expand FMLA coverage by amending definitions of son or daughter to include children of any age, broadening qualifying uses of leave. The 114th Congress considered legislation to expand FMLA coverage by amending definitions to include children of any age and children of domestic partners. The act defines serious health condition as an illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition requiring inpatient care or continuing treatment by a healthcare provider. The FMLA defines a serious health condition as an illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition requiring inpatient care or continuing treatment by a healthcare provider. S. 2584 and H.R. 4616 aimed to amend the act to include recovery from surgery related to organ donation as a serious health condition, but not as the sole criteria. The 114th Congress considered proposals to amend FMLA eligibility requirements for employees, including those related to organ donation. S. 2584 and H.R. 4616 proposed that recovery from organ donation surgery could be considered a serious health condition, but additional criteria would still need to be met for FMLA leave eligibility. The 114th Congress considered proposals to amend FMLA eligibility requirements for employees. H.R. 5518 aimed to reduce the minimum number of employees within 75 miles of an employee's worksite from 50 to 15, while H.R. 5496 sought to remove the 1,250 hours of service requirement. H.R. 5496 proposed to amend hours-of-service requirements by removing the 1,250 hours of service requirement and including part-time and full-time employees as eligible. It did not affect airline flight crew hours-of-service requirements. Additionally, two bills introduced new eligibility requirements for veterans with service-connected disabilities and education support professionals. The bill proposed new eligibility requirements for veterans with a service-connected disability rated at 30% or higher, allowing them to access FMLA-protected leave without meeting the standard employment requirements. A veteran with a disability rated at 30%-50% would be eligible for leave after 8 months of employment and at least 833 hours worked. Employees with a service-connected disability rated at 60% or higher can use leave for medical care after 6 months of employment and 625 hours worked. Certification from a VA medical provider or non-VA facility is required for leave related to a service-connected disability rated at 30% or higher. Employees with a service-connected disability rated at 30% or higher must provide certification from a VA medical provider or non-VA facility. Veterans with a service-connected disability rated at 30%-50% at the time of retirement can use leave for medical care. The bill proposed that veterans with a service-connected disability rated at 30%-50% at the time of retirement could use leave for medical care if employed for 8 months and at least 833 hours in the previous 8-month period. Veterans with a disability rated at 60% or higher could use leave if employed for 6 months and at least 625 hours in the previous 6-month period. Employees with a service-connected disability rated at 30% or higher could access FMLA leave sooner by meeting adjusted eligibility requirements, including being employed for 6 months and completing at least 625 hours in the previous 6-month period. Certification from the Department of Defense regarding the veteran's retirement terms would be necessary for using leave for medical needs related to the disability. S. 3444 proposed adjusting the hours-of-service requirement for educational support professionals (ESP) in public schools or institutions of higher education. An ESP would be eligible for leave if they met the new hours-of-service requirement outlined in the bill. The proposal under S. 3444 adjusted the hours-of-service requirement for educational support professionals (ESP) in public schools or institutions of higher education. An ESP would be eligible for leave if they worked an average of 60 hours per month or 60% of the total monthly hours expected for their job description in the previous 12 months. The Secretary of Labor could establish separate rules for calculating leave entitlement for ESPs without changing the entitlement size available to them.
